case_id: State of Gujarat v. Anirudhsing (1997) 6 SCC 514
facts: Incident occurred during the night between 25th and 26th June 1988 near Khodiar Mata Temple, Jamnagar District, Gujarat.
Accused were police officers: Anirudhsing Jadeja (Sub-Inspector), Nagdan Gadhavi (Head Constable), Naran Meraman Gadhavi (Constable), and Kandhal Sarman Jadeja (Constable).
Prosecution version: The deceased Prabhudas was apprehended by the accused police officers, taken to a secluded place near the Khodiar Mata Temple, and shot dead in a staged/fake encounter.
FIR (Exh. 35) was lodged by accused Anirudhsing himself at Jamnagar Sadar Police Station.

Anirudhsing's FIR version (Defense): While patrolling, they encountered Prabhudas (a known history-sheeter) who fired at the police party first, forcing them to fire back in self-defense, resulting in Prabhudas' death.

Post-mortem report (Dr. Trivedi, PW-1): Multiple firearm injuries found on the deceased. Injury No. 1 was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death. Blackening/tattooing indicated close-range firing for some injuries.
Ballistic Expert Report (PW-20): Confirmed weapons recovered from accused were used. Also indicated close-range firing.

Evidence included: Inquest Panchnama, Site Panchnama, Recovery Panchnamas (revolver from deceased, service revolvers/muskets from accused), witness statements (police personnel, panch witnesses), medical and forensic reports.
Trial Court (Sessions Judge, Jamnagar): Acquitted all accused, accepting the defense version of a genuine encounter and self-defense.

High Court of Gujarat: Reversed the acquittal, convicted all four accused under Section 302 read with Section 34 IPC and Section 201 read with Section 34 IPC. Sentenced them to life imprisonment for murder and 3 years RI for destroying evidence.
The accused police officers appealed the High Court's conviction to the Supreme Court.
ipc_sections: Section 201 (Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The encounter was staged, and the deceased was killed intentionally by the accused police officers acting in furtherance of their common intention.
precedents: Prakash Kadam v. Ramprasad Vishwanath Gupta (2011) 6 SCC 189 (On fake encounters being heinous crimes)
Om Prakash v. State of Jharkhand (2012) 12 SCC 72 (Burden on police to prove justification in encounter deaths)
People's Union for Civil Liberties v. State of Maharashtra (2014) 10 SCC 635 (Guidelines for encounter death investigations)
elements: Death caused by acts of the accused.
Acts done with the intention of causing death.
Common intention shared by all accused to commit the murder.
Act done in furtherance of that common intention.

counter_arguments.loophole: Contradictions in police witness testimonies regarding the sequence of events and firing.
supporting_precedents: Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras AIR 1957 SC 614 (Categorization of witnesses and need for corroboration)
Sujoy Sen v. State of West Bengal (2007) 6 SCC 675 (Impact of material contradictions)

counter_arguments.loophole: Lack of independent witnesses to the actual incident, reliance primarily on police accounts and circumstantial evidence.
supporting_precedents: Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116 (Principles for conviction based on circumstantial evidence)
Kali Ram v. State of Himachal Pradesh (1973) 2 SCC 808 (Prosecution must stand on its own legs, cannot rely on defense weaknesses)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The accused conspired to create false evidence (lodging a misleading FIR, planting weapon) to screen themselves from the offence of murder, constituting an offence under Section 201 IPC.
precedents: V.L. Tresa v. State of Kerala (2001) 3 SCC 549 (Elements of Section 201 IPC)
Kalawati v. State of Himachal Pradesh AIR 1953 SC 131 (Knowledge of offence and intention to screen are key for Sec 201)
Sukhram v. State of Maharashtra (2007) 7 SCC 502 (Sec 201 requires proof of principal offence first)
elements: Commission of the principal offence (Murder under Sec 302).
Knowledge or belief that the offence has been committed.
Act of causing disappearance of evidence of the principal offence OR giving false information respecting the offence.
Intention to screen the offender(s) from legal punishment.

counter_arguments.loophole: If the primary charge of murder (Sec 302) fails, the charge under Sec 201 (screening the offender for murder) cannot stand.
supporting_precedents: Palvinder Kaur v. State of Punjab AIR 1952 SC 354 (Sec 201 conviction unsustainable if main offence not proved)
Hanumant Govind Nargundkar v. State of M.P. AIR 1952 SC 343 (Circumstances must be conclusive and exclude hypothesis of innocence)

defense_arguments.argument: The police party acted in legitimate self-defense after being fired upon by the deceased, a known criminal.
edge_cases: Extent of the right of private defense available to police officers during encounters.
Burden of proof when self-defense is pleaded by police.
precedents: James Martin v. State of Kerala (2004) 2 SCC 203 (Right of private defence principles)
Darshan Singh v. State of Punjab (2010) 2 SCC 333 (Reasonable apprehension of death or grievous hurt for exercising self-defense)
Ex. Ct. Mahadev v. Director General, Border Security Force (2022) SCC OnLine SC 730 (Police justification in using force)

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in reversing the well-reasoned acquittal by the Trial Court, merely substituting its own view on evidence.
edge_cases: Limitations on appellate court's power to interfere with acquittal under Section 378 CrPC.
Presumption of innocence strengthened by acquittal.
precedents: Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (Principles governing appeal against acquittal)
Murugesan v. State (2012) 10 SCC 383 (Acquittal should not be reversed unless trial court findings are perverse or patently erroneous)
Sheo Swarup v. King Emperor AIR 1934 PC 227 (Landmark case on powers in acquittal appeals)

defense_arguments.argument: Prosecution failed to prove common intention (Section 34 IPC) among all accused beyond reasonable doubt.
edge_cases: Distinguishing individual acts from acts done in furtherance of a pre-arranged plan.
Presence at the scene alone is insufficient for Section 34.
precedents: Mahbub Shah v. Emperor AIR 1945 PC 118 (Distinction between common intention and similar intention)
Pandurang v. State of Hyderabad AIR 1955 SC 216 (Common intention requires prior meeting of minds)
Suresh v. State of U.P. (2001) 3 SCC 673 (Common intention can develop on the spot, but requires evidence)

judgment.outcome: Appeal allowed. The Supreme Court set aside the High Court's conviction and restored the Trial Court's acquittal of all accused.
reasoning: The Supreme Court found the High Court's approach in reappreciating the evidence to be flawed.
The Trial Court's view, based on the evidence, that the incident was a genuine encounter resulting from self-defense was a plausible and reasonable one.

Medical evidence (blackening/tattooing) indicating close-range firing was consistent with both the prosecution's fake encounter theory and the defense's self-defense theory during a close confrontation.
The fact that the deceased was a known history-sheeter with prior cases lent credence to the defense version of him potentially being armed and aggressive.
Contradictions and inconsistencies in the testimonies of police witnesses (PWs 4, 5, 6, 7) were noted, which the Trial Court had considered.

The Supreme Court emphasized that an appellate court should be slow to interfere with an acquittal, especially when the trial court's view is reasonable and plausible. Reversal is justified only if the trial court's findings are perverse or clearly erroneous.
The prosecution failed to establish its case beyond reasonable doubt, and the defense version accepted by the Trial Court could not be ruled out.
Since the primary offence of murder (Sec 302) was not proven beyond reasonable doubt, the conviction under Section 201 IPC also could not be sustained.
cited_cases: Sheo Swarup v. King Emperor AIR 1934 PC 227
Surajpal Singh v. State AIR 1952 SC 52
Ajit Singh Thakur Singh v. State of Gujarat AIR 1981 SC 733
Ram Kumar v. State of Haryana AIR 1995 SC 280
Padam Singh v. State of U.P. AIR 2000 SC 361 (Implicitly relevant regarding encounter assessments)

(Note: The judgment text primarily discusses principles of appellate review of acquittal rather than citing numerous specific case laws on encounter facts themselves, focusing heavily on the reasoning of the Trial and High Courts and the principles from cases like Sheo Swarup and Chandrappa).
